html.p: What: I'll give you three guesses as to what it does.

ol.li: Can sort ascending, descending, and a mixture of those.
Can also sort with special fields, like by ip(<field>)

html.p: Why: I mean, come on. Of course you occasionally need to sort things! For a simple and specific case, see also reverse
So What: Often useful after a stats or top/rare or some other "grouping and statistics" function.
Be aware that sort has a built in default limit of 10000. First argument may be a number, and if it set to 0, all results are returned.

panel.html: We're using data we built earlier by using outputlookup. To build this see outputlookup | inputlookup mydata.csv While yours may differ slightly, that data for us is: "_time",salesperson,"Cars Sold This Hour" 1711665905,Rich,1 1711665905,David,1 1711662305,Rich,0 1711662305,David,0 1711658705,Rich,1 1711658705,David,2 1711655105,Rich,2 1711655105,David,3
Sorted most simply, with the default "ascending" on one field, "Cars Sold This Hour"
panel.title: Simple sort

search.query: | inputlookup mydata.csv | sort "Cars Sold This Hour"

panel.html: Flipping the sort to be "descending" for "Cars Sold This Hour"
panel.title: Simple sort, descending

search.query: | inputlookup mydata.csv | sort -"Cars Sold This Hour"

panel.html: More complex sort - "salesperson" ascending (David first), "Cars Sold This Hour" descending
panel.title: Complex sort

search.query: | inputlookup mydata.csv | sort +salesperson -"Cars Sold This Hour"

panel.html: More complex sort - "salesperson" and "Cars Sold This Hour" both ascending
panel.title: Complex sort

search.query: | inputlookup mydata.csv | sort +salesperson +"Cars Sold This Hour"
